Award.AwardTitle: Combinatorial and Algebraic Aspects of Varieties
Award.AbstractNarration:
At the heart of algebraic combinatorics is the philosophy that every aspect of mathematics can be made more precise, more concrete and more computationally feasible by identifying key combinatorial structures. This proposal addresses several specific problems that span a wide range of mathematics including topology, algebraic geometry, representation theory, statistics, computer science and combinatorics. The central theme is to facilitate computation and understanding in these areas. The four areas of research include varieties with combinatorial structures, k-Schur functions, branched polymers, and combinatorial/statistical algorithms for analyzing ordered data.

The work proposed will have a broad impact in several areas of pure math, theoretical physics, computer science and statistics. All of the proposed work will have a computational focus which will further develop algorithms and proof techniques. All of the proposed work will have a human impact component through teaching and mentoring of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs doing research. In terms of education, the PI has initiated a service learning course to address problems in non-profit organizations and small businesses in our community through mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report summarizes an active research program an area of math called algebraic combinatorics.  Progress was made on characterizing  rational smoothness in affine Schubert varieties and generalized  Richardson varieties.  Dual equivalence was extended both to the  affine permutations and to signed permutations.  Enumerative  formulas were given for permutations with a given peak set, and  these results were used to study new probabilistic processes and given  theorems on convergence.  Enumerative formulas for tanglegrams were  given connecting combinatorics with computational biology.  Several  long standing open problems related to conjectures of Macdonald,  Stanley, Fomin and Kirilov were answered positively.  Some of these  conjectures had been open for approximately 25 years.  Finally, a  general enumerative approach to studying parabolic double cosets of  Coxeter groups was studied.


  Nineteen papers were co-written by the PI and collaborators.  These  have all been posted on the arXiv and all are either published or  submitted at this time.  In addition, this grant supported 7  Ph.D. students and 2 master's students through a portion of their  research.  They have submitted and/or published nine additional  papers on which the PI was mentor but not a coauthor.

  Over the period of the grant, the PI was research advisor to 8  Ph.d. students and 3 master's students. All of these students have  graduated except the 4 Ph.d. students who are currently still  completely their PhD under the PI's direction.  The PI also mentored  two postdocs and 16 undergraduates on research project during this  time, many whom have gone on to be very successful in graduate  school.  She also contributed to the research community on a  national level by being an editor on two journals and co-organizing  a semester at the NSF funded center called ICERM and is on the  Policy and Advocacy Committee for the Association of Women in Math.

 


Last Modified: 09/05/2017
Modified by: Sara C Billey
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This report summarizes an active research program an area of math called algebraic combinatorics. Progress was made on characterizing rational smoothness in affine Schubert varieties and generalized Richardson varieties. Dual equivalence was extended both to the affine permutations and to signed permutations. Enumerative formulas were given for permutations with a given peak set, and these results were used to study new probabilistic processes and given theorems on convergence. Enumerative formulas for tanglegrams were given connecting combinatorics with computational biology. Several long standing open problems related to conjectures of Macdonald, Stanley, Fomin and Kirilov were answered positively. Some of these conjectures had been open for approximately 25 years. Finally, a general enumerative approach to studying parabolic double cosets of Coxeter groups was studied. Nineteen papers were co-written by the PI and collaborators. These have all been posted on the arXiv and all are either published or submitted at this time. In addition, this grant supported 7 Ph.D. students and 2 master's students through a portion of their research. They have submitted and/or published nine additional papers on which the PI was mentor but not a coauthor. Over the period of the grant, the PI was research advisor to 8 Ph.d. students and 3 master's students. All of these students have graduated except the 4 Ph.d. students who are currently still completely their PhD under the PI's direction. The PI also mentored two postdocs and 16 undergraduates on research project during this time, many whom have gone on to be very successful in graduate school. She also contributed to the research community on a national level by being an editor on two journals and co-organizing a semester at the NSF funded center called ICERM and is on the Policy and Advocacy Committee for the Association of Women in Math.
